meanings.definition: To make something seem better or more attractive than it really is.
meanings.sent1: She romanticised her vacation photos by adding filters and editing out the flaws.
meanings.sent2: The movie romanticised the life of the main character, making it seem like a fairy tale.
meanings.sent3: He romanticised his cooking skills, but in reality, he burned everything he tried to make.
meanings.sent4: Her memory of the event was romanticised, like a painting that glosses over imperfections.
meanings.sent5: The old house was romanticised in her mind, with ivy-covered walls and a charming garden.

meanings.definition: To view or present something in an idealized or unrealistic way.
meanings.sent1: He romanticised the idea of love, believing it to be perfect and without flaws.
meanings.sent2: The author romanticised the past, depicting it as a time of endless joy and adventure.
meanings.sent3: The child romanticised the idea of being a superhero, imagining flying without any limits.
meanings.sent4: Her dreams romanticised the future, painting a picture of success and happiness.
meanings.sent5: The painting romanticised the landscape, adding vibrant colors and dreamlike details.
